author: agemanning
content:
Hey @fjl nice work! 
I'm on board with the packet modifications. It doesn't seem like a huge amount of implementation overhead. 
In regards to dpi resistance, my preference is to have it also. If we are going to change the packet format might as well add it in now. 
I like the idea that discv5 would then be harder till filter at scale. It costs us larger packet sizes and inevitable headaches in debugging, which I can live with if others can also. However was wondering about WHOAREYOU packets. Sender's won't know the dest IDs so can't encrypt. How are these handled to avoid dpi?

author: arnetheduck
content: I'm curious - since ssl is becoming the norm, companies that offer DPI will more likely be including session/stateful approaches, for example to do SSL MITM-style decoding where the firewall has a legit certificate but obviously not belonging to the original website (which the avg user might not notice) - in the proposal, what could a stateful adversary like this do? would we notice a mitm-style forwarder?

author: arnetheduck
content: also, I'm looking at the quic packet format which has, to a certain extent, a similar structure - if we could coerce the discv5 packets to also validate as quic packets, what would that look like?

author: .fjl
content: <@449019668296892420> since all communication is authenticated, MITM should not work.

content: I'll check out the QUIC format

author: .fjl
content: Ugh, QUIC is a pretty complicated format actually. They do have nice notation in the spec though

author: .fjl
content: <@498009160982724610> > However was wondering about WHOAREYOU packets. Sender's won't know the dest IDs so can't encrypt. How are these handled to avoid dpi?

author: .fjl
content: Maybe you misread it, but the sender will always know the destination ID for any packet.

author: .fjl
content: When a node receives a message packet, the header contains the source ID. This means it can reply with WHOAREYOU with that ID.

author: .fjl
content: Oh, hehe, turns out they actually invented this notation just for QUIC
